title: Access to abortion in France remains fraught with obstacles
summary: Despite the March 4 enshrining of the 'guaranteed freedom' of abortion in the Constitution, there are still obstacles holding back its access.

title: Libor trial: The relentless prosecution of former London traders
summary: Following the 2008 financial crisis, 37 traders made the perfect culprits. Nine of them were imprisoned. They obtained the reopening of their trial, which has just ended.

title: Lasting drought takes hold of Mediterranean region
summary: Water shortages are affecting areas stretching from North Africa to Italy, as well as Portugal, Spain, France, Malta, Romania and Greece.

title: American parents convicted for their child's act of homicide
summary: The father of a teenager who killed four of his classmates at a Michigan high school in 2021, has been found guilty of manslaughter. Despite concerns about setting a risky legal precedent, some see this type of decision as a means of tackling gun ownership.

title: Ukrainian opposition is increasingly critical of the Zelensky administration
summary: A number of MPs are denouncing abusive control on their travel abroad, subject to prior authorization, and are accusing the authorities of trying to stifle their voice.

title: Jared Kushner praises 'very valuable' potential of Gaza's 'waterfront property'
summary: In an interview posted on the YouTube channel of the Middle East Initiative, Donald Trump's son-in-law also said Israel should consider 'moving the people out and then clean it up.'

title: Canada prepares for another dreaded megafire season
summary: In 2023, the North American country experienced its most severe forest fire season on record. The persistence of fires underground, mild winter temperatures and insufficient snowfall have led to fears of a similar scenario this year.

title: Macron launches anti-drug operation in Marseille
summary: The French president arrived in the city unannounced to mark the launch of an operation which according to press reports will require the mobilization of thousands of police.

title: US Supreme Court allows Texas law enabling police to arrest undocumented migrants
summary: The Texas immigration law dispute is among several legal clashes between Texas and the Biden administration regarding border patrol and preventing illegal crossings at the Texas-Mexico border.

title: Paris 2024: Russian and Belarusian athletes excluded from participating in opening ceremony
summary: Announcing their decision on Tuesday, the IOC said these athletes competing under a neutral flag will be able 'to experience the event.'

title: Annual energy conference shows oil isn't going away any time soon
summary: Industry giants gathered in Houston emphasized that global demand was at an all-time high, far from the talk of the end of oil.

title: Brazil's Bolsonaro indicted for first time over alleged falsification of his vaccination data
summary: Released by the Supreme Court, Tuesday's indictment claimed that Bolsonaro and 16 others added false information to a health database to make it look like the then-president, his 12-year-old daughter and several others received the Covid-19 vaccine.

title: Cubans' anger at the regime grows as they suffer from shortages
summary: The island's inhabitants have been dealing with long power cuts and have been forced to wait for days or endure unending queues to have a chance to obtain basic goods.

title: Downhill from here: French authorities halt tourism-focused development at ski resorts
summary: Regional administrative courts have suspended projects to build hotels or extend ski areas.

title: Behind the French dream of entrepreneurship, the reality of bosses earning below the minimum wage
summary: One in five small business owners pays themselves less than the minimum wage. The Covid-19 crisis, which led to the collapse of some businesses, has accelerated this trend.

title: How Paris 2024 intends to be eco-friendly
summary: The organizing committee revealed the initial results of its strategy to create a 'more circular economy' for the Games on Monday. It includes cardboard beds, coffee tables made of badminton shuttlecocks and beanbags made of parachute fabric.

title: French lawmakers move to probe Polynesia nuclear tests
summary: Paris in 2010 acknowledged the health and environmental impacts of the hundreds of bombs detonated in the region, the last as recently as 1996.

title: Ukraine shocked by US delay to pass $60 billion aid package
summary: The $60 billion aid package has been held up for months, as Republican lawmakers insist new funds be linked to more action against illegal immigration.

title: Trump describes recent NATO threats as a 'form of negotiation'
summary: In February, the former US president stated he would 'encourage' Russia to attack NATO members failing to fulfill their financial commitments to the alliance.

title: Benny Gantz, Benjamin Netanyahu's hesitant rival
summary: Since he joined the government after October 7, many see this centrist retired general as an alternative to lead Israel.

title: The Marleys, a golden family
summary: At the top of the English and Jamaican box office charts, the Bob Marley biopic has reached the million mark in France. This commercial success benefits a portion of the family who have continued to keep alive the musical legacy of the reggae legend.

title: 'Free Palestine' plans to participate in the European elections
summary: In France, the Union des démocrates musulmans de France (Union of Muslim Democrats of France) plans to compete in the June elections.

title: Saudi Arabia's faltering hopes on the world football stage
summary: The Saudi authorities have been spending lavishly to attract top players. Female players are also gradually benefiting from this development. But doubts are beginning to surface about the viability of the system, which is deemed too artificial.

title: 'Deepfake,' an imperfect term for an enduring reality
summary: In just seven years of existence, the term has evolved in step with technological innovations. While several countries are considering legislation against these 'fakes' enabled by artificial intelligence, the definition of the word itself remains unclear.

title: Canada stops arms shipments to Israel
summary: The Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister qualified the move to 'cease the further authorization and transfer of arms exports to Israel,' already paused since January 8, as 'a real thing,' and not merely symbolic.

title: French regulator fines Google €250 million
summary: In a decision taken after a settlement procedure France's Competition Authority imposed the €250 million fine on Google for breaching agreements on remuneration for media outlets.

title: Michelin Guide 2024: A welcome breath of fresh air on the prize list
summary: At the Tuesday ceremony in France, 62  restaurants were honored, a third of them less than a year old, and more than half of them run by chefs under the age of 40.

title: Paris 2024: Russian and Belarusian athletes banned from Olympic Games opening ceremony
summary: On Tuesday, the International Olympic Committee announced that athletes from both countries would not be allowed to take part in the parade on the Seine.

title: Sweden's peace activists deprived of subsidies after country joins NATO
summary: The right-wing government, backed by the far right, has cut aid to organizations working for peace and disarmament.

title: 'The entire architecture of global governance is called into question'
summary: The US's refusal to push Israel not to intervene in Rafah has shattered the fragile consensus on condemning Russia for its war in Ukraine, writes Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: Jean Paul Gaultier: 'I've always been flattered when I've been copied'
summary: At the age of 71, the fashion retiree (or so he claims) invites designers to revisit his archives. A way for this 1980s troublemaker, inseparable from corsets and marinières, to stay in the game.

title: Bolsonaro and relatives accused of falsifying Covid-19 vaccination certificates
summary: The former president is alleged to have had forgeries made at the end of 2022, a few days before the end of his term, to travel to the United States, where vaccination was then required. These offenses could land him in prison for up to 12 years.
